<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 514, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the stretching of a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 334, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the set-up.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 128, 761, 389]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 401, 532, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 433, 144, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 433, 677, 452]]<|/det|>
The value \(l_0\) is the length of the spring when the load \(L\) is 0.0N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 464, 866, 483]]<|/det|>
The student measures the length \(l_0\) of the spring. She records \(l_0 = 16 \text{mm}\) in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 744, 514]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram of the spring to show clearly the length \(l_0\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 650, 920, 668]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 146, 700]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 682, 920, 715]]<|/det|>
The student suspends a load \(L = 0.20 \text{N}\) from the spring. She records the new length \(l\) of the spring in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 727, 920, 761]]<|/det|>
She repeats the procedure using loads \(L = 0.40 \text{N}\), \(0.60 \text{N}\), \(0.80 \text{N}\) and \(1.00 \text{N}\). The readings are shown in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 775, 181, 793]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 775, 876, 793]]<|/det|>
Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring for each load using the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 805, 487, 823]]<|/det|>
Record the values of \(e\) in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 822, 920, 841]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 796, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the refraction of light using a semicircular transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 406, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows her ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 128, 803, 603]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 617, 532, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 648, 144, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 648, 180, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 648, 593, 667]]<|/det|>
• Draw a normal **NL** through the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 664, 845, 682]]<|/det|>
• Continue the normal so that it passes through the curved side of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 680, 406, 697]]<|/det|>
• Label the normal **NL**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 694, 660, 712]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{C}\) where the normal **NL** crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 710, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 740, 180, 759]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 740, 920, 774]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line \(\mathbf{DC}\), below line \(\mathbf{PC}\), at an angle \(i = 20^{\circ}\) to the normal and to the left of the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 755, 920, 775]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 787, 180, 805]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 787, 920, 820]]<|/det|>
• Mark with neat crosses (X) the positions for two pins on line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 817, 480, 836]]<|/det|>
• Label the positions \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 833, 920, 852]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
The student looks from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1, to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{AB}\) of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 871, 121]]<|/det|>
She adjusts her line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
She places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), between her eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\), \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 559, 199]]<|/det|>
The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 211, 181, 229]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 210, 809, 227]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 225, 601, 243]]<|/det|>
• Label \(\mathbf{E}\), the end of the line furthest from \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 243, 920, 261]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 273, 181, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 273, 920, 306]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 319, 920, 336]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 312, 532, 330]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 343, 920, 377]]<|/det|>
